title: Molecular and Structural Imaging in Alzheimer's Disease: A Longitudinal Study
description_brief: This is a neuroimaging study designed to learn more about amyloid and tau burden in the brain of patients with typical and atypical Alzheimer's Disease and how burden may change over a one year period.
explanation_target: Reason: The study is a longitudinal neuroimaging/observational study intended to measure amyloid (Aß) and tau burden and structural/functional changes over time in typical and atypical Alzheimer’s disease — i.e., it is diagnostic/biomarker research, not a therapeutic drug trial. citeturn0search0turn0search1

Act (extracted details): Title and description match Mayo Clinic longitudinal imaging work (PI: Jennifer Whitwell). Modalities include Aβ PET (C-11 PiB), tau PET ([18F]flortaucipir / F-18 AV-1451), structural 3T MRI (including resting-state fMRI and QSM), and genetic/blood sampling; serial assessments occur ~12 months apart. No investigational drug or placebo is administered—outcomes are imaging measures of amyloid/tau and rates of change. citeturn0search0turn0search1turn0search5

Reflect: Classification = N/A (does not fit the four therapeutic categories). Rationale: the intervention is imaging/observation (PET/MRI) to quantify pathology and progression rather than a biologic or small-molecule intended to modify disease, a cognitive enhancer, or a neuropsychiatric treatment.
